ENTRY.DEFINITION: An enterprise software platform that provides a unified analytics solution for data engineering, data science, and machine learning, built on top of Apache Spark.
An open-source storage layer that brings ACID transactions to Apache Spark and big data workloads, enabling reliable data lakes.
An open-source distributed computing system that provides an interface for programming entire clusters with implicit data parallelism and fault tolerance.
A centralized repository that allows you to store all your structured and unstructured data at any scale for analytics and machine learning.
A set of properties that guarantee database transactions are processed reliably and ensure data integrity: Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability.
The practice of keeping track of changes to datasets over time, enabling reproducibility and auditability in data processing.
The process of ensuring that data adheres to a predefined schema, preventing corrupt or invalid data from entering the system.
A processing mode where data is collected over a period and processed all at once, suitable for large volumes of data that do not require immediate results.
A processing mode where data is processed immediately as it arrives, enabling quick decision-making and actions based on current data.
The practice of improving the efficiency and speed of data processing systems through techniques like caching, partitioning, and resource tuning.
A multidisciplinary field focused on extracting knowledge and insights from data using scientific methods, algorithms, and systems.
The process of discovering patterns and relationships in large datasets using statistical and computational techniques.
A subset of artificial intelligence that enables systems to learn and improve from experience without being explicitly programmed.
A subset of machine learning that uses neural networks with multiple layers to model complex patterns in data.
A type of deep learning model particularly effective for analyzing visual imagery by using convolutional layers to detect features.
A type of neural network designed to recognize patterns in sequences of data by using loops in the network to maintain information.
The process of optimizing the hyperparameters of a machine learning model to improve its performance on a validation set.
The process of assessing a machine learning model's performance using metrics like accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score.
The process of improving a machine learning model's performance through techniques like hyperparameter tuning, feature selection, and algorithm adjustments.
A set of practices that combines machine learning, DevOps, and data engineering to deploy and maintain ML systems in production reliably and efficiently.
The process of integrating a machine learning model into an existing production environment to make practical predictions based on input data.
The continuous tracking of a deployed model's performance and behavior in production to detect issues like drift or degradation.
The practice of keeping track of different iterations of a machine learning model, allowing for rollback and comparison between versions.
A development practice where developers frequently integrate code changes into a shared repository, triggering automated builds and tests.
An extension of continuous integration that automates the deployment of code changes to production environments after successful tests.
A set of automated processes that allow developers to build, test, and deploy applications more efficiently and reliably.
The process of overseeing a machine learning model's progression from development to deployment and maintenance, ensuring it remains effective over time.
The practice of tracking and managing changes to software code and related assets, facilitating collaboration and history tracking.
The practice of validating machine learning models and code through unit tests, integration tests, and performance tests to ensure reliability and correctness.
An open-source platform for managing the end-to-end machine learning lifecycle, including experiment tracking, model packaging, and deployment.
A Databricks feature that integrates with Git repositories, enabling version control and collaboration on notebooks and code within the Databricks environment.
A command-line interface that allows users to interact with Databricks workspaces programmatically, automating tasks such as deploying notebooks and managing clusters.
An automation platform that allows you to create custom workflows for your GitHub repositories, enabling CI/CD pipelines and other automated tasks.
A data management architecture that combines the best features of data lakes and data warehouses, providing storage for both structured and unstructured data with support for ACID transactions.
Large and complex datasets that traditional data processing software cannot manage efficiently, requiring specialized tools and technologies.
A computing paradigm where computational tasks are spread across multiple machines or nodes, working together to achieve a common goal.
The capability of a system to handle a growing amount of work by adding resources, such as increasing data volume or computational power.
The process of optimizing system configurations and code to improve performance, such as reducing execution time or resource consumption.
A technique used to store frequently accessed data in memory to speed up data retrieval and improve performance.
The process of dividing data into distinct parts or partitions to optimize query performance and resource management.
A technique used in Delta Lake to colocate related information in the same set of files, improving data skipping and query performance.
The process of using statistical techniques and machine learning algorithms to predict future outcomes based on historical data.
Algorithms used in machine learning to learn patterns from data and make predictions or decisions without being explicitly programmed.
A type of recurrent neural network architecture capable of learning long-term dependencies, widely used in sequence prediction problems.
A type of predictive modeling technique that estimates the relationships among variables, often used for predicting continuous outcomes.
A machine learning task of predicting a discrete class label output for an input example.
The process of feeding data into a machine learning algorithm to enable it to learn and make predictions or decisions.
The process of using domain knowledge to extract features from raw data to improve the performance of machine learning models.
The machine learning library of Apache Spark, providing scalable algorithms for classification, regression, clustering, and collaborative filtering.
A model evaluation method that divides data into subsets to train and test the model multiple times, improving the reliability of performance estimates.
A hyperparameter optimization technique that exhaustively searches through a specified subset of hyperparameters to find the best model performance.
The process of finding the optimal set of hyperparameters for a machine learning model to maximize its performance.
A set of practices that combines software development and IT operations to shorten the development lifecycle and provide continuous delivery with high software quality.
The aspect of data science that focuses on practical applications of data collection and analysis, building data pipelines and ensuring data is accessible and reliable.
A statistical method for comparing two versions of a variable to determine which one performs better in a controlled experiment.
A deployment strategy that releases new software to a small subset of users before rolling it out to the entire infrastructure, reducing the risk of introducing bugs.
